trailingComments.value: If the string contains a newline character, we'll split there and recurse

leadingComments.value: If the string contains a newline character, we'll split there and recurse

trailingComments.value: If the string already fits inside `maxWidth` or can't be split, we won't loop through it

leadingComments.value: If the string already fits inside `maxWidth` or can't be split, we won't loop through it
Try guessing how many words to start probing with

trailingComments.value: If the probe index is larger than the actual length of the words array, just start at the end of the array

leadingComments.value: If the probe index is larger than the actual length of the words array, just start at the end of the array

trailingComments.value: Loop backwards through the array of words, starting at the guessed length or from the end

leadingComments.value: Split the array into two chunks and stringify them

trailingComments.value: If the first chunk fits inside `maxWidth` on the first loop, we guessed too low. Restart without guessing

leadingComments.value: If the first chunk fits inside `maxWidth` on the first loop, we guessed too low. Restart without guessing

trailingComments.value:
If the first chunk fits inside `maxWidth`, append it to the finished string.
		   If the second chunk is empty, return `output`, otherwise try again

trailingComments.value:
If the script hasn't returned by now, it wasn't able to split the first index of `words`.
	   Append it to the output and give the end-developer a warning, recursive if there are more words left.

*
 * @fileoverview Methods used in {@link module:eVN/Visuals} for rendering text
* @module eVN/Visuals/text

*Explodes string into an array of strings that won't exceed maxWidth when drawn on ctx * @param {object} ctx - Context to probe .measureText() on * @param {string} string - The string to split * @param {number} fontSize - Font size of the context * @param {number} maxWidth - The maximum width of a string in the returned array (in pixels) * @param {bool} [doGuess=true] - Try estimating the line width using the font size and maxWidth propert * @param {string[]} [output] - An argument used by the function when recursing when concatenating previous attempts * @returns {string[]} An array containing slices of string with a maximum pixel width of maxWidth

*Generate a valid CSS font string
 * @param {string} [size=18] - The font-size to use in pixels
 * @param {string} [family=Comic Neue] - The font-family to use
 * @param {string} [style=normal] - Text style ('normal', 'italic', 'oblique')
 * @param {string} [weight=normal] - The weight to use (i.e. 'bold')
 * @returns {string} valid CSS font property value

*Explodes string into an array of strings that won't exceed maxWidth when drawn on ctx * @param {object} ctx - Context to probe .measureText() on * @param {string} string - The string to split * @param {number} fontSize - Font size of the context * @param {number} maxWidth - The maximum width of a string in the returned array (in pixels) * @param {bool} [doGuess=true] - Try estimating the line width using the font size and maxWidth propert * @param {string[]} [output] - An argument used by the function when recursing when concatenating previous attempts * @returns {string[]} An array containing slices of string with a maximum pixel width of maxWidth
If the string contains a newline character, we'll split there and recurse
If the string already fits inside `maxWidth` or can't be split, we won't loop through it
Try guessing how many words to start probing with
If the probe index is larger than the actual length of the words array, just start at the end of the array
Loop backwards through the array of words, starting at the guessed length or from the end
Split the array into two chunks and stringify them
If the first chunk fits inside `maxWidth` on the first loop, we guessed too low. Restart without guessing

If the first chunk fits inside `maxWidth`, append it to the finished string.
		   If the second chunk is empty, return `output`, otherwise try again

If the script hasn't returned by now, it wasn't able to split the first index of `words`.
